title: 112_hr3899
content: The curr_chunk is a section titled "ROLLOVER OF AMOUNTS RECEIVED IN AIRLINE CARRIER BANKRUPTCY." The curr_chunk discusses the rollover of airline payment amounts to a traditional IRA by qualified airline employees within 180 days of receipt. This rollover contribution can be excluded from gross income in the taxable year it was received. A qualified airline employee can transfer a contribution made to a Roth IRA to a traditional IRA within 180 days of enactment. This transfer can be excluded from gross income. A qualified airline employee can transfer a contribution made to a Roth IRA to a traditional IRA within 180 days of enactment. The transferred amount cannot be treated as a qualified rollover contribution to a Roth IRA within a 5-taxable year period. The employee can file a claim for refund within the period of limitation to reflect the exclusion from gross income. The aggregate amount of airline payment amounts transferred to traditional IRAs for qualified employees in a taxable year is limited to 90 percent of the total payments received by the employee, minus previous transfers in preceding years. Special rules apply for the limitation on airline payment amounts received by the surviving spouse of a qualified employee. Any amount transferred to a traditional IRA by the spouse is treated as received by the employee. Amounts transferred to a traditional IRA attributable to net income are not considered. Covered executives are not eligible to make transfers under certain conditions. For tax purposes, airline payment amounts received by a qualified airline employee are not considered wages if excluded from gross income. This applies to transfers made by a surviving spouse of the employee. The term "airline payment amount" refers to payments made by a commercial airline carrier to a qualified employee under specific conditions set by a Federal bankruptcy court order. The airline payment amount is a fixed obligation of the carrier to pay a lump sum amount to qualified airline employees, excluding future earnings or profits. A qualified airline employee is defined as an employee or former employee of a commercial passenger airline carrier who participated in a defined benefit plan maintained by the carrier. A defined benefit plan for qualified airline employees is described as a plan under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 with a trust exempt from tax, terminated or subject to specific restrictions. A traditional IRA is an individual retirement plan that is not a Roth IRA, while a Roth IRA is defined by the Internal Revenue Code. The surviving spouse of a qualified airline employee can take actions under section 125 of the Worker, Retiree, and Employer Recovery Act of 2008 or this section regarding airline payment amounts. This applies to transfers made after the enactment of the Act for payments made before, on, or after that date.
